author: lendingpond
title: Student Startup escrow (SSE)
description: Students have limited amount of funds and can not risk being scammed by developers and freelancers. There needs to be an consumer protection when young startups outsource jobs and goods.

f6_assessments.q0:
I find the main idea behind the proposal, the development of an escrow service for off-chain services, operated through a smart contract put in place to protect both the seller and the buyer to be worthy of elaboration. However, what I find very problematic, and this is just my perspective, but I really do not find myself enticed to interact with a smart contract that lets any of the both parties burn the funds inside. I don’t necessarily see people as being malicious, but I know errors are very often made, unintentionally, and I know I trust people to make errors all the time. That would be keeping me away from such a service, and I imagine that perhaps others would be too.
So I’m wondering if the smart contract could possibly have another way of functioning, if the team might not be capable of finding another way to keep people truthful, and not as they put it, “force” them into collaboration. Letting people choose to be truthful, in my experience, has always provided better results than trying to force them into that.
In conclusion, I see a good point in building this project, but not as it is designed at the moment. Burning and forcing are not in the ethos of Cardano.
f6_assessments.q1:
The team are already experienced in developing lending services on Cardano, as such, the plan they have provided to implement this project in 5 weeks seems to me to be reasonable. The information for each of the 5 weeks provides ample guidance on how they will be approaching the project and when compared with other projects, the estimate looks reasonable. The budget is obviously on the smaller side, but I imagine that since students will be completing the tasks enumerated, the budget allocated for each one is more of an incentive to participate in the process and learn new things on the way.
I can perfectly understand if not all of the team members are willing to provide their real names, but then I would expect to find a more comprehensive section for each of them, that proves they possess the skills needed to complete the project. What they have provided is just a minimal description, that offers some insight, but I don’t find it sufficient.
The team has also answered “Yes” to the question regarding the submission of other proposals in this current fund, but they have not provided any additional details, or even at least links to them, as is required in the submissions form. 
In conclusion, while the plan and budget look reasonable, the team members’ skills are somewhat left under a question mark and combined with the fact that they have not provided any information about their other proposals, as requested, leaves me in the position to score this section at a 3.
f6_assessments.q2:
The scope of the auditability section is to have a way to provide the Cardano community with the possibility to assess if the implementation process of each specific project is going according to plan, and as such, it needs to have a way to objectively assess its progress. A Twitter space doesn’t seem to me to be a good platform, first of all, because twitter spaces need to be recorded to be kept on the platform, and the recording is then automatically deleted after a period of 14 days. As such, it cannot be considered a reliable source of verification.
And the metrics of social media growth do not necessarily show if the project is on track or not, like for example, a GitHub link with the number of pull requests and forks would.
However, the success part of this section seems to me to be offering sufficient information, and I find the number of 100 student-led projects to be a reasonable number.
In conclusion, the auditability section, at least the first part should, in my opinion, need to be rewritten, to better offer the Cardano Community a way to assess the project’s implementation.

f6_assessments.q0:
A great tool for entrepreneurs of any experience and background, and users in general, is the one formulated by the proposers.  The use cases that can be covered with a scrow contract are numerous and the layer of security they add to each of them is solid.  Being involved in a project that is specifically based on the development of scrow contracts, I am aware first hand of the possibilities that this structure generates.  From the information provided regarding the team's experience it can be deduced that they certainly have the expertise to execute the project they are presenting for funding.  However, as clear as their skills are, it is clear that their profile is outside the guidelines prescribed by the Challenge for which they are applying.  I believe that there would be no objection to this if the stipulation of that profile did not have a valid purpose to justify it. 

The fundamental motivation behind the "Challenge & Scouted for Students" Challenge, approved by the Catalyst community last fund, is to provide college and university students with a space completely separate from the regular Catalyst environment in which they can bring their projects to Project Catalyst and secure base funding, nothing financially ambitious. Clumsy projects, with flaws or weaknesses if any, but with a true innovative and creative student spirit, insolent and daring, that will lead their authors to find in our community a place to learn and get involved, a playground endowed not only with money, but more importantly, with the possibility to get hands on with the best technology in the industry while having access to the knowledge, experience and sense of collaboration of Catalyst members. A new concept for Catalyst no doubt, but an efficient one: in the student community of the planet lies that needle in the haystack that ends up changing the game we play so tightly with other blockchains and the legacy world, and it is our obligation to build the best of the magnets to find it. That's just what this Challenge is trying to do: build a suitable habitat for students, designed primarily by the students themselves. 

Because of my affinity with this Challenge (formal experience in education at school, university, company level) and my experience in Project Catalyst (actively participating in 90% of the community positions that exist: CA, VCA, Challenge Team member, funded proposer, involvement in multiple projects in Catalyst) I have been following it closely since it was approved at F8, because it never ceases to amaze me how often the scoreboard seeks to augment itself with topics of undeniable importance (Developer Ecosystem, Cross-Chain Collaboration, The Great Migration (From Ethereum)) to the point of discarding areas that in the real world have proven to be an inexhaustible source of ideas, creativity and results, such as those related to students.

As an educator and experienced Project Catalyst member involved also in technical projects inside the ecosystem,  I understand the intention behind the proposal and consider it completely valid. However, it is evident that it is not being proposed by the type of students that the Community decided to support through this Challenge, therefore it does not fit the parameters of the Challenge.  I quote (excerpted from the Challenge information): "By creating a category of students and increasing exposure for their ideas, they can expect easier funding and to be scouted by engineers" (section What does success look like?). "Most student entrepreneurs suffer from a shortage of resources, especially when it comes to funding and hiring engineers" (Why is this important? section). "However, the number of proposals to Catalysts is increasing rapidly, and the community does not readily perceive small-scale proposals from students. .... Therefore, to make it easier for the community to recognize new ideas from students, we will establish a new category exclusively for students" (Challenge brief section). 

Taking into account the above reasoning, I must remove three stars from the final rating.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposers would probably agree that this type of project deserves a little more depth of detail at the implementation plan level.  As someone involved in this type of project I see this as necessary to assess the technical strengths of the project and I am sure that colleagues or others knowledgeable in the field will find this necessary as well.  It is actually a paradox: the low level of detail would be understandable if the proposers were college or university students in full exercise of their student status, however, as experienced players in the field, they should be aware of the level of detail in the information provided.  

The reduced level of detail presented in the implementation plan is also a rule in the budget description.  Therefore, as an evaluator, there are many assumptions that must be made to give the proposal a chance of successful execution.

The lack of detail in the information provided in the Feasability section leads me to reduce the final rating by two stars.
f6_assessments.q2:
There is no direct relationship between the measurement parameters provided in the Auditability section and the performance of the proposal.  The development of twitter spaces and their corresponding number of attendees does not have any relationship with the status of the service to be built.  The same is the case for the growth of the twitter account and the discord server.

On the other hand, there is no clear methodology to reasonably establish how the leap towards the future vision stated in the subsection "What does success for this project look like?" of the Auditability section will be made.    The project as a whole does not offer the arguments to establish the possibility of such progress.

Therefore, I must be in complete disagreement in terms of auditability, which means removing 4 stars from the final rating.

f6_assessments.q0:
Problem identified by proposer is one of the many factors that discourage students to even try. For those that has been in the crypto space for a while now surely can testify on how the industry has been weaponized to commit fraudulent activities globally. While originally smart contracts are designed so activities can be verified via code and release funds, it doesn’t tackle activities that are done and can only be checked in the physical world. This solution if I understood it right is an all or nothing deal, meaning both parties (a student entrepreneur and a skilled worker) both provides security deposit and will risk losing both funds if one or the other chooses to burn and the only way both parties will “win” is if both have an agreement that “work is done”. It is indeed an interesting social-financial experiment. 

Although it is worth mentioning that there’s no clear indication on what would happen on the “burnt” funds. I suggest the proposer to add details about this as it would be good to know if there’s any economic value for anyone for this to happen. Like, will this be used to pay for the operational expenses, donated to charity or just simply taken out of circulation permanently.

I can see this solution being used by proposers on this challenge in the future.
f6_assessments.q1:
Five weeks timeline can be enough with the proper number of resources to work on this project full-time however it’s not mentioned on how the work will be divided and by whom? He listed one smart contract developer but it’s not clear if the same resource would work for the frontend and backend. Proposer mentioned that they’re a team of 6 but missed to provide details on the other 4. Though it is worth noting that proposer has provided a working project he had work on (lendingpond.app). 

Details on the plan are somewhat lacking as well. Here’s my comments for each “sprint”.

•	Week 1 – Would love to know what research is expected as an outcome in a one-week work? Would this be for the UI Design, functions included on the app? Or refining activities on the timeline? 
•	Week 2/3/4 – What sections/functions will be included and completed in the front-end, backend, contracts? Login page? Review/comment Section? Work postings? Worker’s Profile? 
•	Week 5 – are we expecting a demo video, social media engagement and open beta for public to test? 


Answers to above questions are highly critical on how we can measure feasibility, while theoretically it is possible for a short amount of time but to manage our expectations and detailed breakdown would help. As it stands it’s unlikely. 


Budget is aligned to what a month’s work would be worth for frontend and backend developer (at least in Asia). Though I like the proposer’s confidence that funding will be enough if carefully planned, question remains on the scope of work. As a project manager myself gauging a timeline’s feasibility can only be measured if taken against the amount of work per client’s specification. Given that the proposer has the creative control on what the overall design, functionality would look like it would be nice if that can be shared publicly in detail.
f6_assessments.q2:
It’s great that proposer host twitter space and communicates in discord but maybe loop us in on what accounts will be used for these so we can join in and engage? 

As for the development progress, there’s no mention of repository site we can track. Github perhaps? 

I would also recommend that you identify proper measures of success of the project. Launching a dApp is just one part. Once it’s operational you’ll need a concrete way to measure if it’s doing excellent or not. This can include number of daily users, total paid amount to workers, failed contracts or anything that would show your dApps performance objectively. Always remember that transparency is a key factor for the community to back your projects.

f6_assessments.q0: The team aims to build a smart escrow to prevent student-led projects from being scammed by freelancers when outsourcing their work. This helps improve the accountability of stakeholders and the transparency of transactions conducted in the Cardano ecosystem, making it a better place for its members in terms of finance. The proposal gives a pretty clear description of their solution. We see the goal of their product (supporting students and startups with modest funds via secured transactions done with smart contracts) and its direct audience (students, startups, freelance developers, etc. signing smart contracts about outsourcing). I understand that this benefits the Cardano system and brings more users to it. However, the team doesn’t mention any key metrics or KPI to show that the proposal is closely aligned with the challenge. The team foresees some risks that they may face when conducting the proposal, and presents some solutions to mitigate those risks.
f6_assessments.q1:
The team provides a 5-week plan to carry out this proposal. Each week comes with a task. I suppose the details of each week, like the expected results of each milestone, should be elaborated on so as to increase the understanding and feasibility of the project.
The budget is broken down into 4 parts (Server and domain $500, Artist and front end $1000, Backend $2000, and Smart Contract development $2500). The total budget here makes $6000 while the total requested fund of the project stated in the beginning is only $5000. Some adjustment needs to be made here to clear this gap.
The proposal gives some description of the two members who will be working on the project. Unfortunately, no references like Linkedin profiles are provided to help understand who the team members are and things they are doing to ensure if their competence matches the requirement of this proposal.
f6_assessments.q2:
The team plans to track their project’s progress by holding bi weekly twitter spaces and taking note of the number of attendants. This method will be a lot easier to be audited if some specific numbers are included here.
The description of what success for this project looks like is pretty nice as the team sets a quantified goal of attracting 100 student-led projects using their startup escrow system. This number is a good means to base on when it comes to project auditability.
